definitions: bring goods or services into a country from abroad for sale
have importance or significance for a particular matter or situation
examples: The company imports electronic components from several Asian countries
Japan imports most of its oil from the Middle East
These findings import a great deal to our understanding
The decision imports serious consequences for the industry

definitions: force something unwelcome or unfamiliar to be accepted or put in place
officially establish and enforce a rule, tax, or punishment by authority
examples: She didn't want to impose her beliefs on her children
The guests imposed on their host's hospitality for weeks
The government imposed strict regulations on carbon emissions
The court imposed a heavy fine on the corporation

definitions: seize and take legal custody of something, especially a vehicle or animal
collect and confine water in a reservoir or dam structure
examples: The police impounded his car for illegal parking violations
Animal control officers impounded several stray dogs yesterday
The dam impounds millions of gallons of water annually
Engineers designed the structure to impound seasonal rainfall

definitions: transfer computer files between systems using the File Transfer Protocol
examples: Please ftp the documents to the server before midnight
The developer will ftp the updated code this afternoon

definitions: mark or stamp a surface or object by applying pressure
fix an idea or image indelibly in someone's mind or memory
examples: The machine imprints the company logo on each product
She imprinted her initials on the leather wallet carefully
The traumatic event imprinted itself on his memory forever
Early experiences imprint behavioral patterns in young animals

definitions: put someone in prison as a legal punishment for a crime
keep someone in a severely restricted or confined situation metaphorically
examples: The court decided to imprison him for ten years
The authorities imprisoned several political activists without trial
Her fears imprisoned her in her own home constantly
The debt imprisoned them in a cycle of poverty

definitions: make something better in quality, value, or performance through modification
become better in condition, quality, or performance over time
examples: The company improved its customer service through staff training
Regular exercise will improve your overall health significantly
Her piano playing has improved dramatically this past year
The weather should improve by the weekend forecast shows

definitions: create and perform music, drama, or speech spontaneously without preparation
produce or make something from whatever materials are readily available
examples: The jazz musicians improvised brilliantly during the concert performance
The actor had to improvise when he forgot his lines
We had to improvise a shelter using branches and leaves
The chef improvised a delicious meal from leftover ingredients

definitions: make something inactive or no longer functional in operation
destroy the biological activity of a microorganism, enzyme, or virus
examples: The administrator will inactivate your account after ninety days
Please inactivate the alarm system before entering the building
High temperatures inactivate most bacteria within minutes of exposure
The vaccine contains inactivated virus particles for safety purposes

definitions: begin or introduce a new system, policy, or period formally
admit someone formally to public office with a special ceremony
examples: The university will inaugurate a new scholarship program next year
This event inaugurates a new era of international cooperation
The president will be inaugurated on January twentieth traditionally
They inaugurated the new mayor with great ceremony yesterday

definitions: prevent someone from functioning normally through injury or illness
prevent something from functioning or operating effectively in any capacity
examples: The accident incapacitated him for several months of recovery
A severe migraine can incapacitate a person completely today
The cyberattack incapacitated the company's computer network entirely yesterday
One faulty component can incapacitate the entire production line

definitions: embody a deity, spirit, or quality in physical or human form
represent or be a perfect example of a quality or idea
examples: Many religions believe their deity incarnated as a human
The legend says the god incarnated himself as a warrior
She incarnates the spirit of determination and hard work
The villain incarnates pure evil in the story completely

definitions: make someone extremely angry or indignant about something unfair
examples: The judge's biased ruling incensed the defendant's family completely
His dismissive attitude incensed everyone at the meeting yesterday

definitions: move slowly and carefully in small increments or with difficulty
examples: The climber inched along the narrow ledge very carefully
Traffic inched forward during the morning rush hour congestion

definitions: encourage or stir up violent or unlawful behavior in others
urge or persuade someone to act in a violent or unlawful way
examples: The speaker's words incited the crowd to riot violently
Social media posts can incite hatred between different groups
The rebels tried to incite the population against the government
His inflammatory speech incited violence in the streets yesterday

definitions: lean or turn away from a vertical or horizontal position
have a tendency or preference toward a particular characteristic or behavior
make someone willing or disposed to do something favorably
examples: The path inclines steeply as it approaches the summit
She inclined her head to listen more carefully nearby
He inclines toward conservative views on economic policy matters
The evidence inclines me to believe her story completely
Years of experience incline her to be cautious always
His friendly manner inclines people to trust him immediately

definitions: have something as a part or element of a whole
make someone or something part of a group or collection
examples: The price includes breakfast and dinner at the hotel
The museum collection includes several paintings by famous masters
Please include me in your weekend plans this time
The teacher includes all students in classroom discussions equally

definitions: cause trouble, difficulty, or discomfort to someone in their activities
examples: We apologize if the construction work inconveniences you today
The delayed flight inconvenienced hundreds of passengers last night

definitions: take in or include something as part of a whole structure
form a company or other organization into a legal corporation
examples: The architect will incorporate sustainable materials into the design
The recipe incorporates traditional spices from several different cultures
They decided to incorporate their business for tax advantages
The partners will incorporate in Delaware next month officially

definitions: make something greater in size, amount, intensity, or degree
become greater in size, amount, intensity, or degree over time
examples: The company plans to increase production by twenty percent
Exercise can increase your energy levels throughout the day
Sales have increased steadily over the past three quarters
The population continues to increase at an alarming rate

definitions: make someone appear guilty of a crime or wrongdoing through evidence
examples: The new evidence could incriminate several high-ranking officials today
He refused to answer questions that might incriminate him

definitions: sit on eggs to keep them warm until they hatch naturally
develop slowly without obvious signs before emerging or manifesting
maintain organisms or cells at optimal conditions for growth
examples: The hen will incubate her eggs for twenty-one days
Some birds incubate their eggs by burying them underground
The disease can incubate for weeks before symptoms appear
The startup incubated its innovative idea for two years
Scientists incubate bacterial cultures at thirty-seven degrees Celsius precisely
The laboratory incubates tissue samples in controlled environmental conditions

definitions: instill an idea, attitude, or habit by persistent instruction or repetition
examples: Parents should inculcate good values in their children early
The military inculcates discipline through rigorous training programs daily

definitions: become subject to something unwelcome or harmful as a result of actions
examples: The company incurred huge debts during the economic recession
You may incur additional charges for late payment penalties

definitions: bind someone by an indenture as an apprentice or laborer legally
examples: Historically, poor immigrants were indentured to work for passage
The apprentice was indentured to the master craftsman formally

definitions: create an alphabetical list of items with page references systematically
adjust wages, prices, or payments automatically according to an index
link or relate one thing to another as an indicator
examples: The librarian will index all the new books tomorrow
Search engines index billions of web pages every day
The government indexes pensions to inflation rates annually now
Many contracts index payments to the consumer price index
Scientists index climate changes to carbon dioxide levels globally
Economists index various indicators to predict market trends accurately

definitions: point out or show something, especially using a gesture or sign
be a sign or symptom of a particular situation or condition
state or express something briefly or indirectly to someone
examples: The guide indicated the emergency exits with his hand
The arrow indicates the direction to the main entrance
Dark clouds indicate that a storm is approaching rapidly
These symptoms indicate a serious underlying medical condition possibly
She indicated her preference for the blue dress subtly
The survey results indicate strong support for the proposal

definitions: formally accuse or charge someone with a serious crime legally
examples: The grand jury voted to indict him on fraud charges
Federal prosecutors will indict the suspects next week probably

definitions: succeed in persuading or influencing someone to do something specific
bring about or cause a particular state, condition, or effect
bring on childbirth or abortion artificially, especially with drugs
examples: Nothing could induce her to change her mind today
They induced him to invest in their startup company
The medication may induce drowsiness in some patients occasionally
Stress can induce various physical and mental health problems
The doctor decided to induce labor due to complications
They will induce the birth if contractions don't start

definitions: allow oneself to enjoy the pleasure of something desired
satisfy or give way to a desire, interest, or person
examples: She decided to indulge in chocolate cake after dieting
They indulge themselves with luxury vacations every summer regularly
Parents shouldn't indulge their children's every whim constantly
He indulges his passion for collecting vintage cars extensively

definitions: contaminate a person, organism, or cell with a disease-causing organism
affect a person with strong feelings or emotions that spread
contaminate a computer or network with malicious software or virus
examples: The bacteria can infect wounds if not properly cleaned
One sick person infected dozens at the conference unknowingly
Her enthusiasm infected everyone in the room with excitement
His pessimism infected the entire team's morale negatively yesterday
The virus infected thousands of computers within hours worldwide
Hackers infected the network with ransomware last night deliberately

definitions: deduce or conclude information from evidence and reasoning rather than explicit statements
examples: Scientists can infer climate patterns from tree ring data
The detective inferred the suspect's motive from the evidence

definitions: be present in large numbers, typically causing damage or disease
examples: Termites infested the old wooden structure throughout the foundation
Weeds have infested the garden during our vacation absence

definitions: enter or gain access to an organization or place surreptitiously
permeate or spread gradually through something like a liquid
examples: Spies managed to infiltrate the enemy organization successfully yesterday
Protesters infiltrated the secure building during the night shift
Water had infiltrated the foundation causing significant structural damage
The ideology slowly infiltrated every aspect of their society

definitions: fill a balloon, tire, or other expandable structure with air or gas
increase something by a large or excessive amount artificially
exaggerate the importance or value of something beyond reality
examples: Please inflate the tires to the recommended pressure level
The children inflated colorful balloons for the party decorations
Speculation tends to inflate housing prices in urban areas
The company inflated its earnings reports to attract investors
He tends to inflate his role in the project
Media coverage inflated the significance of the minor incident

definitions: cause something unpleasant or painful to be suffered by someone or something
examples: The hurricane inflicted massive damage on coastal communities yesterday
He would never inflict pain on another person intentionally

definitions: have an effect on the character, development, or behavior of someone or something
examples: Her teacher greatly influenced her decision to study medicine
Social media can influence public opinion on important issues

definitions: give someone facts or information about something important or relevant
pervade or be a formative element or quality throughout something
examples: Please inform the manager about the delivery delay immediately
The police informed her of her rights before questioning
A sense of urgency informed all their subsequent decisions
Historical context informs our understanding of these events today

definitions: actively break the terms of a law, agreement, or copyright
examples: The company was sued for infringing several technology patents
New regulations must not infringe upon citizens' constitutional rights

definitions: soak ingredients in liquid to extract flavor or healing properties
fill someone or something with a particular quality or emotion
introduce a substance directly into the bloodstream through medical procedures
examples: Infuse the tea leaves in hot water for five minutes
The chef infused olive oil with fresh herbs overnight
The coach infused the team with confidence before the game
Her paintings are infused with vibrant energy and emotion
The nurse will infuse the medication intravenously over two hours
Doctors infused saline solution to treat severe dehydration quickly

definitions: take food, drink, or another substance into the body by swallowing or absorbing
examples: Children sometimes ingest harmful substances accidentally at home
The patient must not ingest solid food before surgery

definitions: live in or occupy a place or environment as a resident
examples: Various species of birds inhabit this tropical forest year-round
Humans have inhabited this region for thousands of years

definitions: breathe in air, gas, or vapor into the lungs deliberately or naturally
examples: The doctor asked her to inhale deeply during the examination
Don't inhale the toxic fumes from the cleaning products

definitions: receive money, property, or a title from someone after their death
derive a quality, characteristic, or predisposition genetically from ancestors
examples: She will inherit her grandmother's entire estate next year
The eldest son traditionally inherits the family business here
Children inherit traits from both of their biological parents
He inherited his mother's musical talent and artistic ability

definitions: hinder, restrain, or prevent an action or process from happening
slow down or prevent a biological or chemical process scientifically
examples: Fear of failure can inhibit creativity and innovation significantly
Strict regulations inhibit business growth in this sector considerably
This drug inhibits the growth of cancer cells effectively
Certain chemicals inhibit enzyme activity in metabolic pathways naturally

definitions: mark or sign a document with one's initials as authorization
examples: Please initial each page of the contract before signing
The manager must initial all changes to the document

definitions: set a computer program or system to its starting position or value
examples: The technician will initialize the new hard drive tomorrow morning
You must initialize all variables before using them properly

definitions: cause a process or action to begin officially or formally
admit someone into a society or group, typically with a ritual
examples: The government will initiate new economic reforms next month
She initiated legal proceedings against her former employer yesterday
The fraternity initiates new members every fall semester traditionally
They were initiated into the secret society last night

definitions: force a liquid, especially a drug or vaccine, into the body with a syringe
introduce a new or different element into something suddenly
examples: The nurse will inject the vaccine into your upper arm
Diabetics often inject insulin several times throughout the day
His comments injected humor into the serious discussion yesterday
The company wants to inject fresh capital into the project

definitions: do physical harm or damage to someone's body through accident or attack
examples: The fall from the ladder injured his back severely
Three people were injured in the car accident yesterday
